basics.name: Kenneth Hahn
basics.label: Process Engineer
basics.summary: A results-driven Chemical Engineer with four years of experience in manufacturing, specializing in process optimization and data-driven decision-making. Currently transitioning into the Data Science field, leveraging a strong analytical background and hands-on engineering experience to drive business decisions and create impactful solutions. Passionate about using data to solve complex problems and eager to contribute to a forward-thinking organization.

courses: Research Design and Applications for Data and Analysis
Solid State Mechanics: Statics and Dynamics

work.name: Tesla
work.summary: Optimized manufacturing process for the Model S, Model X, Cybertruck, and other undisclosed model battery packs, contributing to enhanced production efficiency, quality, and safety.
highlights: Created process for a new subassembly line via Postman API calls to parallelize workload and increase production of battery packs by 33%.
Decreased electrical resistances in battery pack to assist in safe operation of the vehicle, resulting in a statistical reduction of 57,430 defects per million to 98 defects per million.
Utilized A/B testing to determine supplier quality issues with fasteners, leading to a 20% yield percentage increase.
Improved leak test processes utilizing statistical process control, reducing the number of off-roaded vehicles and saving the company $800K/year.
Developed Tableau Dashboards to monitor critical equipment metrics for the new Cybertruck launch.

work.name: Procter and Gamble
work.summary: Improved hydrogenation reaction process to develop alcohol hydrocarbon products, minimized unplanned downtime, and ensured optimal reaction conversions.
highlights: Experimented and executed an increase to site throughput of Fatty Alcohol Product by 1%, resulting a site revenue gain of approximately $3M/year, without the use of capital spending.
Utilized process control strategies to tune a pressure control valve to allow higher pressures in the reactors. This led to a 0.2% increase in reaction completions and overall throughput.
Used problem solving tools to reduce water usage in the site, leading to a 100 GPM reduction in well water usage.
Saved the business $120K/year by optimizing flow rates of caustic through experimental tests.
Eliminated 10% of nuisance alarms through MATLAB, collecting occurrence data and determining root cause for each.
